I played this game on the ps4 and I enjoyed it! I thought it was an interesting storyline and the difficulty level on normal was good enough for me to handle (I am not great at games). However, I recently got a new pc and decided to buy the game again because I heard of all the new updates and DLC, and it is like a whole new game. The skill tree is seamless and feels like it has a lot more weight to it. The weapon system is much more understandable. I haven't got to the new DLC but I am excited to see how it adds to the story. Overall, its super fun to replay and discover new ways to play the game!

I own Elden Ring and it's DLC for both PS5 and Steam. I like it.

ELDEN RING is the culmination of decades of design and while it isn't perfect, it's a more than worthy entry in a genre essentially invented by its spiritual predecessors. The Souls-Like has defined a generation of gaming and the medium is better off for it. There's something to be said about a best-selling entry in a franchise among the greatest of all time being a singleplayer, box product in a market saturated with live-service multiplayer and predatory monetization. We can only hope that the success of ELDEN RING teaches big studios the right lessons.

TL;DR: Solid 8/10 Main Game

Pros:
-Fantastic lore/world building
-Fantastic gameplay
-Huge world with things to do
-Great graphics/art direction
-Phenomenal soundtrack 
-Easy to get into for casual gamers, with plentiful options to make the game significantly easier

Cons:
-PC stuttering caused by shader compilation
-Certain bosses reward good RNG for a run instead of only outplaying them, however every boss is beatable with pure skill alone even if the boss uses their hardest/cheesiest moves. For example beating Malenia felt more like getting a good run than out-skilling her,
-World is vast but does not reward exploration for your specific build (i.e. there's no point in exploring if you already have a build in mind with specific talismans, etc.). Basically if there's nothing you need in a certain area then there's no point going there except for leveling purposes.
-Final boss of the main game is one of the worst main bosses

My Build:
-Melee only strength/stagger build with a two-handed colossal great sword, lion's claw, talismans that boost this playstyle, no summons, no cheesing bosses

Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.  Fool me three times, uninstall the game.

The Terry Bogart DLC has just released and the pattern is now clear: They are not trying to create a balanced eSport, but are releasing OP characters to sell DLC!

Every new DLC character release is like a recreation of the Stanford Prison Experiment.  Half the players switch to the new character and get to be wardens, and half the players stick with their main character and get to be prisoners.

Having to fight a constant loop of Terry, Bison, and Akuma is not fun any more.   The only successful DLC characters were Ed and Aki.  They were different enough to attract some attention, but not so overpowered that everyone switched to them.  The pattern with Akuma, Bison, and now Terry is clear.  Buy the DLC character and you get to play as a warden.  Dont buy the character and you are a prisoner. 

I do not recommend anyone buy this.  The launch was good and surprisingly balanced, but this is now a pay2win-ish game.

Easily one of the best if not [b]the[/b] best Street Fighter to date. (Next to Third Strike)
Every match feels challenging but still winnable, it's not a snowball-fest like other games.

There's serious hype potential in every match, and the characters are varied and fun to learn.
The netcode has been pretty good to me so far, and the battle hub is hilarious to behold.

Oh, and it has a single-player adventure mode similar to ye olde Mortal Kombat Konquest!

What's not to love here? Except for maybe a pretty meager starting roster as of writing.

Hopefully SF6 has a long and prosperous future ahead of it, compared to SFV.

I was wary of playing Cyberpunk's base game after the reviews when it just came out, but grew increasingly curious about the game after watching the anime. After finally folding and purchasing the base game at a discount, I quickly grew to love the combat system, methods of gaining power, and especially the story the game told. The most important part of any game to me is the story, followed by the combat mechanics, then the graphics. Cyberpunk smashed all my expectations so much so that I purchased Phantom Liberty at full price when I was halfway through the game, solely because I knew I wanted more content before the end of the game. I'm very glad I did. The DLC has been wonderful, and without spoiling it, I would rate it 2 tiers above the base game (7/10 - base, 9/10 DlC, for an average of 8/10). Note that 5/10 simply means "average" and reasonable for the experience/price. I fully recommend the DLC if you enjoyed the base game.

"Balls to the Wall" -- completely bugged.

1. For some reason, when the chase starts and you get hit by a car and continue driving, we did not continue. Our car got pushed to the gate and didn't move. I had to restart.
2. Then when you start fighting scavs, it's needlessly hard. It's my 2nd playthrough, on hard difficulty. On hard, I killed Adam Smasher on 2nd try at just lvl 35 with sucky cyberware, and I'd say Adam Smasher is one of the hardest bosses in the game. This thing took me 5 tries. My advice -- when you get out of car, you get blades. Forget the blades, get back to pistol, find cover and be very careful as they'll shred you very quickly. Be careful with skulls and netrunners. First time I got killed by a runner.
3. After finally doing this, I go to the "wounded scav" and... nothing happens. It's bugged again. Trust me, I tried everything and I don't think I did anything unusual to cause it. 

At this point I just lost it. Come on, The DLC had been out for a year now, and the base game is 4 years old at this point. I understand that making games of this scale is hard. Even after 4 years, in the base game content, I still encounter some small bugs but I'm like "okay, no biggie". But this is just not acceptable quality.

ending made me cry.

An excellent story based DLC spy story addition to CP2077. The start and the finish of the story are cinema worthy in their scope and dramatic work. It does rather lag in the middle whilst you go and do other jobs to fill in time until the main plot resumes. However, this is more an issue with the genre rather than this DLC in particular.
The voice acting is very good, the new weapons, items and locations are good, though most of the good work was done by the 2.0 patch to the base game.
Overall, a very good addition to CP2077, and here's hoping for more, or for similar quality in the next game.

It's shocking to believe that this expansion is something that came out as good as it did despite the base game. The main story to this DLC is a lot more linear than the base game's, and it is all the better for it. There is focus, there is amazing pacing. The characters introduced are likable, which is far more than I can say for quite a few of the characters in the base game. There were decisions given to the player that were hard to make. The game, through these decisions, makes you ask what it is that is important to you. Is it ideals, loyalty, freedom, what aspect of life do you value? And who will suffer for your decision to follow these ideals? It is an excellent narrative with an amazing musical score, great story and wonderful writing, and I cannot recommend it enough. Leagues better than the base game.

TL;DR stop looking at reviews and play the game! Cyberpunk 2077: Phantom Library is one of the best expansions to one of the best games ever made. I have a gtx 1070 and it ran fine at 1080p most of the time I played at high or ultra but I had to turn it down to medium sometimes.

In my honest opinion Phantom Liberty has some of the best story telling of any game I've played in 40+ years. It's the closest thing I've encountered to really giving you that Blade Runner experience where every choice you make really has consequences not just for your character, but for the entire world of Cyberpunk, and just like the world of Blade Runner there really are no happy ending. I haven't experienced that kind of make you sit back and reflect on the things that you did to get you where you had to go since Geralt found Ciri in The Witcher 3. I look forward to enjoying it again. Phantom Liberty is immersive story telling at its best.
One of the Best Story DLCs I've seen in recent years. Loved the story and sat a solid 10 minutes at the end pondering what decisions to make.

An extremely well polished thriller. I was absolutely hooked! As I mentioned in my review of the base game, the decisions you make in the base game and DLC, and their consequences stay in your mind even long after you're done playing the game.

The game is in a very good state now than it was at launch, and I highly recommend playing it now if you didn't back when it launched.

I was 13 years old when I got this game, to give you a frame of reference im 25 now. I was always excited for the npc update and I get that somethings were out of their control such as their servers being stolen years ago or it was wiped I cant exactly remember. This game was a blast and I understand the devs are working hard on the npcs and I hope its worth it, but ive waited over a decade of my life to see semblance of what would change this game forever. They've been dangling this carrot in front of us for over a decade. Its actually wild. At one point npcs were talked about so much that they started muting and banning people over it. I don't blame them. What I do blame them for is how long this has taken. Over a decade really? No transparency until recently. Used to be my favorite devs, now i'm just sad. B42 now to B43, I feel like npcs are never gonna happen. 


Maybe instead of perfecting a decade old game you guys should complete this product and move on to the next with bigger and better ideas. 
Maybe you guys should realize we aren't looking for perfection and looking for more gameplay mechanics to extend the life of this game. 

How about you fix your shit with player feedback?

Or is the code so far gone you are gonna push back the date for eternity or until you tell us its scrapped? 

I'm only saying this out of a place of love for the game you guys have made and as a 
disappointed customer.

To one of my favorite devs to a team I no longer believe in, I sure hope you guys release what you promised over a decade ago.

I have been playing this game off and on for the last year or so. I enjoyed the vanilla version of the game, but I really started to enjoy it with the many mods that are able to be implemented. It helps make a realistic game a little more realistic, definitely worth the cost and you can find yourself getting lost in the lore and gameplay.

The longer you survive, the more you'll care about surviving but in the beginning I couldn't even muster the motivation to care that I was dying. Everything is a chore, literally. Yes, its mechanics are deep and interesting. And I can understand why someone would find satisfaction in a game like this but if you're looking to play a game... I don't even know if this qualifies as a game. It feels more like taking care of a really shitty tamagotchi.

Before I get into the negatives, I want to be very clear: this is one of my favorite games ever. I am a huge fan of the 2018 GoW, and this game actually improves on it in nearly every way. I wish that I could be writing a positive review right now, because this game absolutely deserves it... on console.

I bought the steam port the second it came out, and ever since, it has been fundamentally broken. I have no idea why most other reviewers aren't commenting on this, but this port is unplayable as it stands. I can repeatedly cause it to crash to desktop simply by looking at the in-game menus. If you want to read the in game lore, the game will crash the second you select any other item than the one it initially opened on, eg. Kvasir's Poems. The game also crashes during certain fights seemingly at random. And all of this will occur after closing the game and reopening to play later from your last save, which is a very normal thing to do.

I am running the game on an asus zephyrus laptop, with a 3080 gpu, as well as 8gb of vram. I am well within the bounds of recommended specs, and run intensive games all the time with no problems whatsoever. I have tried almost every combination of settings, both in and out of the game, but to no avail. I have scoured what little there is online, and amazingly, turning it off and on again doesn't fix an in-game bug, or bugs.

I have to imagine that all the good reviews are from people who haven't picked up this game since the first time opening it, or who have only played it on console. When this bug, or bugs, is fixed, I will immediately come back and edit this review to be glowing. Game requires a restart every so often to avoid performance loss from VRAM usage going up and up with loading and transitioning between different realms and other assets not getting flushed fast enough from GPU memory. 

If you have less than a 16GB GPU you can experience issues earlier (depending on your in-game settings and resolution) like audio de-sync, texture pop-in and crashes. There are many other issues with the use of different controllers and issues with mouse and keyboard input. 

I will now sit on the wait train for patches.

It's not the controller as it works fine on any other game I use. Also crashed a few times while fiddling in the steam controller menu. Whoever was in charge of controller/steam deck support for this game needs to get fired. It's a shame, because the game is great, but can't reccomend a game this broken. I've played every GOW including the original trilogy on PS and GOWR is by far the most boring, drawn out, and uninteresting of the lot of them.
 
I have gotten to the mission with Atreus and [spoiler]Angrboda[/spoiler] and I have to take a break from this game as this mission in particular is a pungent combination of every aspect that makes this game so awful...

[*] The game features an Incredibly drawn out level design that forcefully diverts attention from the main objective without creating any sort of interest in whatever else that's going on. 
[*] The dialogue/voice acting takes away from the immersion of the mission and rarely adds anything of substance to the world (Sindri, Brock, and a few others are exceptions to this). 
[*] The combat system feels inconsistent and fights including bosses feel less "cool" then in the other games. 
[*] The puzzles/path discovery needed to advance within missions feels redundant, unoriginal, and often times unnecessary. 
[*] And IMO the armor/weapon upgrade UI feels unrefined and outdated. 

These issues are dramatically present in the mission mentioned above but are featured throughout the ~9 hours of gameplay I've experienced so far.

On the plus side the graphics and cut scenes look amazing, and the main story so far is awesome, in spite of how hard the developers tried to destroy the interesting aspects of the story through an incredibly poorly thought out gameplay experience. 

IMO this game is nowhere near worth the $60 price tag and I heavily regret spending that amount on this game. I would seriously wait for it to go on sale somewhere below the $30 mark. 

I will most likely end up completing the main story, just for nostalgias sake, and immediately uninstall it.

You kill monsters and make cool hats out of them, what's not to love.

Monster Hunter: THE WORLD is an action-style third-person beat em up, slice em up, carve em up, drink em up, KILL THEM ALL, where you play as John World, or the Joker and his normal cat. As we find and research the world's most amazing and charismatic megafauna so we can "peacefully" relocate them to the afterlife.

Do you ever regret not being born in time to hunt Siberian mammoth, or perhaps you're the kind of man who opens carries to the zoo, waiting for the day that the chimps become excited?

If so, this game could be for you.

Set in the hostile and exotic wasteland of Australia, we play as an inherently bloodthirsty and violent race known only as Caucasoidis Anglicus, and we are here to destroy the local environment as much as humanly possible...

So I can wear it.

Along the way, overcoming many varieties of horrifying creatures unknown to God. Ranging from plausible and interesting specimens to fucking Thanos. And yes, I am reviewing Monster Hunter: World, and not Rise, because the phrase Nintendo Switch port does not fill me with confidence. I'm sure it's a fantastic game, but it looks like an excellent Garry's Mod map.

So, without further ado, I hope you enjoyed my explanation and review of my favorite animal cruelty simulator with a game attached to it.

An amazing game with many praise worthy qualities, such as the beautiful visuals, fantastic soundtrack and combat that is genuinely fun to get good at. However, there are several things that weigh the experience down. The story forcing you to load into quests solo, watch the unskippable cutscene, then have you or your friend leave their instance in order to play together is a major pain point. The lack of  proper weapon tutorials hurts on-boarding for new players, as they need to consult third party guides just to understand how their weapon functions. Menus are annoying at best and unintuitive at worst. While most of the issues I've mentioned so far are minor in the grand scheme of things, a major gripe I have with the game has to do with the unequal treatment of weapons in regard to dealing elemental damage. Having half of your arsenal be objectively inferior to just using a weapon with more raw damage hurts build diversity, and is incredibly disappointing when you want to build around a monster's weakness, only to end up doing worse because your weapon isn't good for elemental damage. Also having the Frostfang Barioth Charge Blade be impact phial was just evil.

Is this a good monster hunter game? Yes. Do I think it's perfect? Far from it.

Pros:
* Amazing cutscenes
* Decent story for a Monster Hunter game
* The weapons feel good to use (at least the ones I tried)
* Most of the new monsters have great designs and fights
* The mantles are a decent new addition

Cons:
* The clutch claw is not only janky with nonsensacle physics, it is necessary to beat most late game monsters in iceborne if you're playing alone and it made my favorite weapon type (Dual blades) unusable until the post game of the DLC without making insane builds for each monster
* Cutscenes are unskippable even on a second playthrough and make playing through the game with friends a nightmare with how they're implemented
* Most of the weapon designs not only look like trash, they don't even match the respective armor well

Don't get me wrong, the game is amazing and I recommend playing it, but these issues just really bother me and I'm glad most of these seem to be fixed in MH Wilds
